info.game_comments:
1997 International Tournament semifinal game 1.
  From Stockholm, Sweden.

(1, 1).clue: Some citizens in this Canadian capital get their news from the Citizen newspaper

(2, 1).clue: In the 1500s the Portuguese transported Angolans as slaves to this South American colony

(3, 1).clue: You saw thousands of spots before your eyes in the 2 Disney movies about this number of dalmatians

(1, 2).clue: Xinhua, China's news agency, was founded by this political party

(2, 2).clue: In 1969 General Siad Barre led a military coup in this country on the horn of Africa

(3, 2).clue: In the Biblical flood, the rain lasted this many days; the water stayed 110 more

(4, 2).clue: When bringing home the bacon, remember that this animal's meat is taboo to observant Muslims & Jews

(5, 2).clue: On July 8, 1993 this British princess' stepmother, Raine Spencer, married a French count

(1, 3).clue: It's the length of time between issues of Germany's news magazine Der Spiegel

(2, 3).clue: Shaka increased the population of this tribe by absorbing his defeated enemies into it

(3, 3).clue: On a square, it's the total number of degrees of the interior angles

(4, 3).clue: A "maid" may have a special stool to sit on while attending to this bovine animal

(5, 3).clue: She was sworn in as Pakistan's first female prime minister on December 2, 1988 in Islamabad

(1, 4).clue: El Periodico de Catalunya is the second-largest newspaper serving this second-largest Spanish city

(2, 4).clue: This west African country takes its name from a trading empire that once included Timbuktu

(3, 4).clue: John Lennon & Paul McCartney were in their 20s when they wrote "When I'm" this old

(1, 5).clue: Now available around the world, this paper grew out of the N.Y. Herald's Paris edition

(3, 5).clue: From 1912 to 1959 there were this many states in the United States

(1, 1).clue: The running of these animals starts daily at 8 A.M. during the Festival of San Fermin in Pamplona, Spain

(2, 1).clue: In 1504 Leonardo da Vinci was on the commission that decided the location for this man's "David"

(3, 1).clue: At the National Museum in Dublin you can see a bell reportedly used by this patron saint

(4, 1).clue: Around 3600 B.C. King Menes of Egypt set this precious metal's value at two-fifths that of gold

(6, 1).clue: Many of these English Christmas songs are translations, like "Silent Night" from German

(1, 2).clue: This second-largest Australian city's Moomba Festival features a world-class waterskiing tournament

(2, 2).clue: The name of the Farnese bull comes from the Farnese Palace in this Italian capital where it was once kept

(3, 2).clue: Not surprisingly, this Israeli national airline offers the most nonstop flights between Israel & the U.S.

(4, 2).clue: By volume, this element makes up about 78% of our atmosphere

(5, 2).clue: He was a U.S. senator when he married Jacqueline Bouvier in 1953

(6, 2).clue: Gilbert Adair faithfully adapted Georges Perec's novel "A Void", written without this vowel

(1, 3).clue: In 1996 Wayne Shorter & Dave Brubeck performed at Vienna's festival for this type of music

(2, 3).clue: In 1881 this Cubist painter & sculptor was born in Malaga, Spain, the son of a professor of art

(3, 3).clue: In Moscow's Teatralnaya Square, you can take in a show at this famous opera & ballet theater

(4, 3).clue: Diamond, the hardest known substance, is made of crystallized atoms of this element

(5, 3).clue: On June 15, 1775 he was unanimously elected Commander in Chief of the Continental Army

(6, 3).clue: Translator Rosemary Edmonds leaves the final "A" off the last name of this Tolstoy title heroine

(1, 4).clue: "Abduction from the Seraglio" is performed at Topkapi Palace at this city's annual music festival

(2, 4).clue: A Cellini masterpiece shows this Greek hero holding the head of Medusa

(3, 4).clue: Verses from the Koran decorate the walls of this marble tomb in Agra built by Shah Jahan for his late wife

(4, 4).clue: This metal, the lightest solid element, was discovered here in Sweden by J.A. Arfvedson

(5, 4).clue: A revolving book stand he adapted may be seen at his home, Monticello

(6, 4).clue: 2 translators of this man's "The Satanic Verses" were brutally attacked in July 1991

(1, 5).clue: Yearly this small southeast Asian island country celebrates the 9 Emperor Gods with a 9-day festival

(2, 5).clue: Toronto's City Hall has an outdoor work by this British sculptor known for using holes in his art

(3, 5).clue: Tourism is a growing industry in this pair of Caribbean islands known as T&T for short

(4, 5).clue: This synthetic radioactive element was named for the discoverers of radium

(5, 5).clue: In 1859, before he was president, he wrote, "He who would be no slave must consent to have no slave"

(6, 5).clue: Rabindranath Tagore translated his own poetry into English from this language spoken in Dhaka

(0, 0).clue: On January 30, 1997, the 49th anniversary of his death, some of his ashes were scattered in the Ganges River
